name: SNAC
body:
### Sensor Networks for Autonomous Cars SNAC is a system designed for use in the next generation of autonomous cars. Currently, it is capable of the following: * Counting the number of cars in opposing traffic * Speed estimation of cars in opposing traffic * Logging GPS and any OBD data Utilizing this information, it is capable of traffic estimation, primarily using monocular vision. When combined with a wireless communication network, in theory, it will be able to generate crowdsourced traffic information. Some features to be implemented in the future: * Mapping capability to geographically store data * Robust detection of various traffic signs (stop signs, yield signs, speed limit signs, etc.) * Detection of obstacles (cars stopped on the road, accidents, major potholes, etc.)

### The system This is the in car assembly of the SNAC system: Sensors:
1 x Omnivision OV10635 USB 3.0 Camera
1 x Garmin GPS18-5Hz
1 x On-board Diagnostics II (OBDII) Sensor


### Demo

### Methods ![System workflow](http://i.imgur.com/KnY3Xta.jpg) testfasfa * opencv optical flow (farneback) * neural network - trained yolo (reference paper and site) architecture on VOC car images. this gives bounding boxes * bounding box metadata is enough to be able to count how many opposing cars pass by. * with the culmination of optical flow and bounding box data, a logistic classifier predicts the speed of the vehicle. * finally greenshield's eq, which requires the count and speeds, outputs a traffic estimate.

### Authors center

Pavan Purohit (left) and Ajay Srivastava (right)
{as1877, pp428}@rutgers.edu

Working under the supervision of PhD student Gorkem Kar & Professor Marco Gruteser
{gkar87, gruteser}@winlab.rutgers.edu
